title: Bristol Stool Form Scale
description: Classifies stool form and correlates with intestinal transit time to assess bowel health and identify constipation or diarrhea

result.name: classification
result.description: Clinical classification and transit time assessment

ranges.interpretation: Severe constipation. Hard, separate pellets that are difficult to pass. Indicates prolonged colonic transit time with excessive water absorption. Requires dietary modifications (increased fiber and fluids) and possible laxative therapy.

Mild constipation. Hard, lumpy stools that are somewhat larger but still difficult to pass. Indicates slow colonic transit with increased water absorption. Requires increased fiber intake, hydration, and physical activity.

Normal bowel function (lower normal range). Sausage-shaped with surface cracks. Represents adequate hydration and fiber intake with normal colonic transit time. Generally considered healthy stool consistency.

Ideal bowel function. Smooth, soft, sausage-shaped stool that is easy to pass. Represents optimal hydration, diet, and normal colonic transit time. This is the target consistency for healthy bowel movements.

Normal bowel function (upper normal range). Soft blobs with clear-cut edges that pass easily. May indicate slightly faster colonic transit or higher water content. Generally acceptable but monitor for progression to diarrhea.

Mild diarrhea. Mushy stool with fluffy pieces and ragged edges. Indicates rapid colonic transit with reduced water absorption. May be caused by dietary factors, medications, or mild gastrointestinal conditions.

Severe diarrhea. Watery stool with no solid pieces. Indicates very rapid intestinal transit with minimal water absorption. May lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalance. Requires medical evaluation if persistent.

references: Lewis SJ, Heaton KW. Stool form scale as a useful guide to intestinal transit time. Scand J Gastroenterol. 1997;32(9):920-4. doi: 10.3109/00365529709011203.

Heaton KW, Radvan J, Cripps H, Mountford RA, Braddon FE, Hughes AO. Defecation frequency and timing, and stool form in the general population: a prospective study. Gut. 1992;33(6):818-24. doi: 10.1136/gut.33.6.818.
O'Donnell LJ, Virjee J, Heaton KW. Detection of pseudodiarrhoea by simple clinical assessment of intestinal transit rate. BMJ. 1990;300(6722):439-40. doi: 10.1136/bmj.300.6722.439.
formula: Visual classification based on stool morphology: Type 1 (separate hard lumps) to Type 7 (entirely liquid)
notes: Developed at Bristol Royal Infirmary in 1997 by Stephen Lewis and Ken Heaton
Widely used research tool for evaluating bowel treatments and as clinical communication aid
Forms part of diagnostic criteria for irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)
Types 3 and 4 are considered normal and ideal stool consistency
Scale correlates inversely with colonic transit time
Validated in multiple languages including Spanish, Brazilian Portuguese, and Polish
Should be used alongside clinical history and examination for comprehensive assessment
